Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Hathor. Naked Hathor with her hands to her sides and modelled in the round. Her hair falls in divided locks on her upper back and on her shoulders. She wears a necklace with two large beads and a pendent amulet, perhaps an animal or a crescent. Apparently solid, from two-piece mould. Now missing head and legs below knee. Brown Nile silt, with abundant fine gold mica, quartz and some white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Close parallel from a Graeco-Roman context at Tanis (Brissaud 1994, 15, fig. 1b). Similar examples from a favissa at Ras el-Soda, Alexandria, dating to the Ptolemaic period, perhaps 3rd to 2nd century BC (Adriani 1952, pl. 14, 1), one from Gabbari, Alexandria, was dated end of 3rd, beginning of 2nd century BC (Kassab Tezgör 2001, 421, fig. 12.14), dated 4th to 3rd century BC (Fischer 1994, no. 806; Fischer 1995, pl. 44, 1; Vogt 1924, pl. xci, 6) and others dated to the Ptolemaic period (Török 1995, no. 210; Fischer 1994, 75n. 25 and 329: no. 807). However, another was dated 1st to 2nd century AD (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, no. 246), whilst examples from Edfu (Henne 1925, pl. 28, 9) and Memphis (Petrie 1909, pl. 35, 9, Petrie Museum UC33573) are not given specific dates. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Henne, H. 1925. Condition: Head is lost and figure is broken away below the knees.
